sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Aspergillosis, Invasive: (salvage therapy) 100 to 150 mg/day IV; optimal dose not established
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, high-risk patients; Prophylaxis: (salvage therapy) 50 mg/day IV
  • Candida endophthalmitis: (alternative therapy) 100 mg/day IV for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Candidemia: (primary therapy) 100 mg/day IV infusion over 1 hour; mean duration of therapy (clinical studies), 15 days (range, 10 to 47 days)
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection: 100 to 150 mg/day IV
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection: (alternative therapy) 100 mg/day IV for at least 2 weeks, followed by fluconazole therapy
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: 150 mg/day IV infusion over 1 hour; mean duration of therapy (clinical studies), 15 days (range 10 to 30 days)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (alternative therapy) 100 mg/day IV for 14 to 21 days (guideline dosing)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection: 150 mg/day IV infusion over 1 hour; mean duration of therapy (clinical studies), 15 days (range, 10 to 30 days) OR 14 to 21 days (guideline dosing)
  • Disseminated candidiasis: 100 mg/day IV infusion over 1 hour; mean duration of therapy (clinical studies), 15 days (range, 10 to 47 days)
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic: (alternative therapy) 100 mg/day IV for 1 to 2 weeks, followed by oral fluconazole therapy when clinically stable
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation; Prophylaxis: (primary therapy) 50 mg/day IV infusion over 1 hour; mean duration for prophylaxis (clinical studies), 19 days (range, 6 to 51 days)
  • Empirical antifungal therapy, Suspected candidiasis in nonneutropenic patients: (primary therapy) 100 mg/day IV until cultures and/or serodiagnostic tests are negative
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (fluconazole-refractory) 150 mg IV daily
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (alternative therapy) 100 mg/day IV
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis, Chronic (cavitary or necrotizing): (salvage therapy) 100 to 150 mg/day IV (optimal dose not established)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients younger than 4 months
  • Candidemia: 2 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour once daily; MAX 100 mg/day
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (30 kg or less) 3 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour once daily
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (greater than 30 kg) 2.5 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour once daily; MAX 150 mg/day
  • Disseminated candidiasis: 2 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour once daily; MAX 100 mg/day
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation; Prophylaxis: 1 mg/kg IV infused over 1 hour once daily; MAX 50 mg/day

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • hepatic impairment (mild, moderate, or severe): no dosage adjustment necessary
  • geriatric: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • hemodialysis: supplemental dosing is not necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Candidemia
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, high-risk patients; Prophylaxis
  • Candida endophthalmitis
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic
  • Empirical antifungal therapy, Suspected candidiasis in nonneutropenic patients
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Invasive fungal infection; Prophylaxis
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis, Chronic (cavitary or necrotizing)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: known hypersensitivity to micafungin, any components of the product, or other echinocandins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hemolytic anemia and significant hemolysis (including acute intravascular hemolysis) have been reported
  • hepatic abnormalities (eg, liver function test (LFT) abnormalities, hepatic dysfunction, hepatitis, and hepatic failure) have occurred; patients on multiple concomitant medications with serious underlying medical conditions may be at increased risk; monitoring recommended in patients who develop abnormal LFTs
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis and shock, have been reported
  • renal dysfunction (eg, BUN or creatinine elevations, acute renal failure) has occurred; monitoring recommended in patients who develop abnormal renal function tests

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micafungin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (treatment, 7% to 13%; prophylaxis, 51% to 77%), Nausea (treatment, 7% to 10%; prophylaxis, 70% to 71%), Vomiting (treatment, 7% to 18%; prophylaxis, 65% to 66%)
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (treatment, 9%; prophylaxis, 72% to 75%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (treatment, 9%; prophylaxis, 44%)
  • Other:Fever (treatment, 7% to 13%; prophylaxis, 61%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Atrial fibrillation (treatment, 3% to 5%), Cardiac arrest (less than 5%), Myocardial infarction (less than 5%), Pericardial effusion (less than 5%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (treatment, 18%; prophylaxis, 51%), Hemolysis, Hemolytic anemia, Intravascular hemolysis
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Encephalopathy (less than 5%), Intracranial hemorrhage (less than 5%), Seizure (less than 5%)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure, Renal impairment, acute

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Micafungin sodium is a semisynthetic lipopeptide (echinocandin) antifungal agent, synthesized by a chemical modification of a fermentation product of Coleophoma empetri F-11899, that inhibits the synthesis of 1,3 beta-D-glucan, a fundamental constituent of fungal cell walls.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, IV, premature infants: 1.2 hours
  • Tmax, IV, pediatrics: 0.84 to 2.01 hours
  • Tmax, IV, adult lung transplant patients: 4 hours

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd, adults: 0.39 L/kg
  • Vd, premature neonates: 0.39 to 0.76 L/kg
  • Protein binding, Albumin: more than 99%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: P450 CYP3A, arylsulfatase, and catechol-O-methyltransferase, hydroxylation
  • Metabolites: M-1 (catechol form), M-2 (methoxy form). and M-5

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: approximately 40% (drug and metabolites)
  • Fecal: 71%
  • Renal: 15% or less unchanged
  • Dialyzable: No
  • Total body clearance: adults, 0.204 to 0.301 mL/min/kg
  • Total body clearance: pediatrics with weight 30 kg or less, 0.328 mL/min/kg; weight greater than 30 kg, 0.241 mL/min/kg
  • Total body clearance, pediatrics: 28.52 to 42.72 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance: premature neonates, multiple dose, 89 mL/hr/kg (1 mg/kg/day); 0.4 mL/min/kg (7 mg/kg/day); 0.6 mL/min/kg (10 mg/kg/day)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Adults, 10.7 to 17.2 hours
  • Premature neonates, 5.5 to 11 hours
  • Pediatrics patients aged 4 months to 16 years,12.5 hours (30 kg or less); 13.6 hours (greater than 30 kg)
  • Pediatric patients aged 2 to 17 years, 12 to 21 hours; less than 5 years, 10.13; 5 years and older, 13.81 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • add 5 mL D5W or NS without bacteriostatic agent to each 50-mg or 100-mg vial to yield a concentration of 10 mg/mL or 20 mg/mL, respectively; gently swirl vial, do not vigorously shake vial during reconstitution
  • (adult) add appropriate volume of reconstituted dose to 100 mL NS or D5W
  • (pediatric) withdraw appropriate volume of reconstituted solution from vial based on calculation of required dose (ie, pediatric dose [mg/kg] x weight of patient [kg]) divided by concentration of solution in reconstituted vial (ie, either 10 mg/mL or 20 mg/mL); add withdrawn volume to an NS or D5W infusion bag or syringe, ensuring that final concentration of solution is between 0.5 mg/mL to 4 mg/mL; if final concentration of solution is greater than 1.5 mg/mL, label the bag or syringe for administration via central catheter
  • protect diluted solution from light; no need to cover the infusion chamber or the tubing
  • administer within 24 hours of dilution
  • (infusion) infuse over 1 hour; do not administer as an IV bolus injection
  • do not mix or co-infuse with other medications
  • an existing IV line should be flushed with NS prior to infusion

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• CBC
  • liver function tests (monitor for worsening in patients who develop abnormal liver function tests during therapy)
  • renal function tests (monitor for worsening in patients who develop abnormal renal function tests during therapy)

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Mycamine
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 50 MG, 100 MG
  • NovaPlus Mycamine
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 50 MG, 100 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• May cause headache, skin rash, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of renal or liver dysfunction.
